title.narrative: Swe Tax Agency - Kenya Revenue Auth

description.narrative:
Insatsen är ett institutionssamarbete mellan svenska skattverket (SKV) och kenyanska skatteverket (KRA). Målet med insatsen är att öka skattintäkterna och bredda skattebasen genom att stödja KRA i att förbättra analysen av risker relaterade till skattedisciplin samt öka och förbättra KRAs fokus på skattebetalarna som kunder.
Institutionssamarbetet är uppdelat i tre komponenter: 1) Data Warehouse Business Intelligence System (DWBI); 2) Rikshantering; 3) Change management. DWBI är ett datasystem för att samla information från flera idag separata datasystem inom och utanför KRA. DWBI kommer att ge KRA en överblick över varje skattebetalare och därmed också ge ett bättre underlag för riskanalys så att riskgrupper och riskområden kan identifieras och KRAs skattrevisioner etc. kan fokusera på de mest strategiska områdena och grupperna. Sida kommer även att stödja upphandlingen av DWBI systemet direkt med 35 miljoner svenska kronor. Detta stöd är direkt kopplat till institutionssamarbetet men kommer att avtalas och beslutas separat. Parallellt med utvecklandet av DWBI kommer SKV också att stödja KRA i att utveckla sin ansats till riskanalys, komponent två. Den tredje komponenten, change management, handlar dels om att öka KRAs inre effektivitet genom att förbättra efterlevanden av KRAs mål, värden och principer, dels handlar den om att öka och förbättra KRAs fokus på skattebetalarna som kunder.
Institutionssamarbetet inkluderar en långtidskonsult från SKV som kommer att arbeta i Kenya på heltid, samt korttidkonsulter som kommer på 1-3 veckors uppdrag inom de olika områdena. En viss del av externa konsulter kommer även att ingå i programmet.
Institutionssamarbetet sträcker sig från juli 2014 till december 2019.

The contribution is an institutional collaboration between the Swedish Tax Agency (STA) and Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA). The objective is to increase tax collection and broaden the tax base by supporting KRA in improving the analysis of risks related to tax compliance as well as increase and improve KRA's customer focus.
The institutional collaboration is divided in three components: 1) Data Warehouse and Business Intelligence System (DWBI); 2) Risk management; 3) Change management. DWBI is a data management system to gather information from many separate data systems within and outside of KRA. DWBI will give KRA a single view of each of the tax payers and hence also improve the basis for risk analysis so that risk groups and risk areas for tax compliance can be identified and KRA's tax audits and other interventions can focus on these strategic areas and groups. Sida will also suppor the procurement of the DWBi system directly with 35 MSEK. This support is directly related to the institutional collaboration but will be decided and agreed separately. In parallell with the development of the DWBI STA will support KRA in developing their approach to risk management, component two. The third component, change management, aims partly to improve KRA's internal efficiency by improving the staffs' compliance with KRA mission, vision, values and principles, and partly to increase and improve KRA's customer focus.
The institutional collaboration includes one long-term expert (LTE) from STA that will work in Kenya full time, and several short-term experts (STEs) that will come for 1-3 weeks misssions within the different areas. Some external consultants will be engaged in the program.
The institutional collaboration covers the period from July 2014 to December 2019.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
17.1 - Strengthen domestic resource mobilization, including through international support to developing countries, to improve domestic capacity for tax and other revenue collection.
17.1 - Stärka den inhemska resursmobiliseringen, inklusive genom internationellt stöd till utvecklingsländerna, för att förbättra den inhemska kapaciteten att ta upp skatter och andra intäkter.

description.narrative: Key documents Final narrative report: Kenya Revenue Authority and Swedish Tax Agency, “Cooperation Programme Between Kenya Revenue Authority and Swedish Tax Agency 2014 – 2019: Final Report September 2014-June 2019” (2019-11-01) Evaluation of the support: Greg Moran, Anders Jansson and Jack Ranguma, “Evaluation of the Sida-supported development cooperation with the Kenya Revenue Authority,” Draft Final Report (Embassy of Sweden in Nairobi and NIRAS Sweden AB, 16 August 2019)[1] 2nd technical audit of DWBI: Steve Darko and Saber Bhar “Technical Assessment of the Risk Management, Data Warehouse and Business Intelligence Project for the Kenya Revenue Authority” (BDP LLP, May 2019) 1st technical audit of DWBI: “Annual external audit of the Swedish support for the procurement of a Data Warehouse and Business Solution: Technical assessment of Data Warehouse and Business Solution Project for the Kenya Revenue Authority” (Embassy of Sweden, Moore Stephens LLP and Baken Tilly Merali’s, December 2017) Results Risk management results: *“Establishment of the Strategy, Innovation and Risk Management Department and the Corporate Risk Management Committee *“Strategic risks have been incorporated in the 7th Corporate plan *“A Corporate Risk Management matrix is now used by departments to develop their own risk management plans *“KRA has a well-developed process for RM and provides training to the managers. *“Through the Transformation Agenda, the KRA has started their journey to become a data based, risk based and intelligence driven organisation. *“Through hands on exercises, KRA has started to build capacity for case selections by using the Data Warehouse. *“Structures and framework for RM are in place and sensitisation has been done to create understanding and awareness of the RM process” (Final Narrative Report, p. 26). Data Warehouse results: “The Data Warehouse support consisted of both institutional and capacity development provided by STA as part of this project, and the procurement of the DWBI as part of a separate contract between Sida and KRA, co-financed by Danida and the Government of Kenya. “The support in this Component was hampered somewhat by the delays in the procurement of the data warehouse itself. “Since an entire Data Warehouse is not yet in place, the Components objective has not been achieved. However: *“KRA’s capacity has been significantly built and Phase 1 of the system is already having an impact on risk analysis and management within KRA *“A pilot Roll out of Phase one, Risk Analysis and Case Management to KRA operations started in May 2019” (Final Narrative Report, p. 27). Change management results: *“Change management has become totally integrated into the structure of KRA through the establishment and operations of the Transformation Leadership Office *“KRA has started their journey to institutionalize Culture Change within KRA. KRA has refined their Vision to be A Globally Trusted Revenue Agency facilitating Tax and Customs compliance (Seventh Corporate Plan 2018/19-2020/21). *“Through the Transformation Agenda, business operation expects to be data based, risk based and intelligence driven. *“Another expectation is progress from a feared and bureaucratic tax authority to one that fosters voluntary tax compliance through building trust and facilitation. *“In 2017 KRA started their transformation towards an Intelligent Tax Administration that efficiently uses data and the massive digital capabilities at their disposal to revolutionize service delivery during the period 2017-2020” (Final Narrative Report, p. 28). Realized risks: Some of the most important program risks that became a reality were that: *The long-term expert was not kept informed about key developments at KRA. *Key KRA staff were often called away at the last minute, meaning that they were not available when program missions took place or that the purpose of training changed at the last minute because unexpected participants had needs different from those of the intended participants. This latter risk is common in this kind of intervention, but in the case of the KRA/STA intervention, the parties were unable to deal with the risk more effectively. Since all funds were channeled via STA, the corruption risks associated with funding KRA were avoided.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
